sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It was hope and frustration for UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres during his visit to Ukraine's crucial port of Odessa on the Black Sea.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Addressing reporters, Guterres celebrated grain shipments restarting after a deal was reached between Russia and Ukraine in recent weeks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: In less than a month, 25 ships have departed from Odessa and other Ukrainian ports, loaded with grain and other food supplies.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They have carried well over 600,000 tons of food products and counting wheat, corn, sunflower oil, soya beans.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: But Guterres says there is still more work to be done.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: As these ports open, I appeal for wealthier countries to also open their wallets and their hearts.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: After all, the movement of grains doesn't mean much to countries that cannot afford it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Lower prices on the global food markets don't mean much if those prices aren't reflected in local food markets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Ukraine's trading routes via Poland, Romania and Turkey faced disruption after Russia's invasion in February.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: But a landmark agreement means crucial grain shipments are now operating from the country's southern ports, partially alleviating fears of a food shortage crisis.
